title: El Nino rains threaten tourism in Eastern African states
text:
El Nino rains threaten tourism in Eastern African states   
By Apolinari Tairo, eTN Tanzania Correspondent | Aug 26, 2015 eTN   
TANZANIA (eTN) - Weather and meteorological scientists in East Africa warned about possible heavy rains to hit this part of Africa next month. The scientists who are meeting in Tanzania’s capital city of Dar es Salaam have warned of possible El Nino rains and have warned residents and travelers booked to visit this part of Africa to be vigilant as these heavy downpours will destroy the communications network. 
Tanzania Meteorological Agency (TMA) Chief Executive Officer Dr. Agnes Kijazi said the El Nino weather phenomenon was due to warming of the Pacific Ocean and is to affect the Eastern African region in September. She said a weather forecast had indicated a possible El Nino phenomenon. 
Weather scientists are participating at the two-day 41st Greater Horn of Africa Regional Climate Outlook Forum (CHACOF-41), that brought together weather experts from 11 countries in the Greater Horn of Africa (GHA), a region extending from Ethiopia to Tanzania, bordering the Indian Ocean coast. 
The experts are planning and developing a joint consensus on the regional climate outlook for September to December 2015, the period which in this part of Africa experiences short rains. 
They are meeting together discussing the theme, “The Provision of climate early warning for early action regarding expected 2015 El Nino impacts.” 
The Kenya Meteorological Department has issued a warning to the Kenyan people, saying it was waiting to receive more reports of weather forecasts from scientists meeting in Tanzania. 
El Nino hit East Africa in 1997 causing heavy rains, floods, as well as cholera and malaria outbreaks, while roads across the region were cut-off by heavy floods. 
Tanzania had most of its roads leading to wildlife parks damaged, while airports were closed for landing and taking off for several hours. 
Weather experts have advised the Tanzanian government to take serious caution to avoid losses in transport and communication infrastructure which are poorly developed. Most roads in Tanzania are not paved to sustain heavy rains, while some paved roads are of poor standard. 
Dar es Salaam airport, the main air connecting point in Tanzania, is poorly equipped with adequate facilities to control heavy rains and air traffic, and also to smoothly facilitate boarding and landing of passengers.
